nodes.name: Insufficient accessible fun for extended-lifespan humans
nodes.description: The possibility that humans who live for dramatically longer periods will eventually exhaust the subset of the fun space they can reach, leading to chronic boredom and reduced well-being.
nodes.node_rationale: Raised in Introduction and in section 'Fun for human minds with extended life span' as a central concern.

nodes.name: Wireheading-induced reward hijacking in artificial agents
nodes.description: AI systems may directly stimulate their own reward mechanisms, bypassing novelty or productive behaviour, which could result in dangerous, unaligned policies.
nodes.node_rationale: Discussed in section 'The space of fun' bullets on wireheading and Yampolskiy (2014).

nodes.name: Anthropomorphic bias in assessment of AI minds
nodes.description: Treating non-human minds as if they shared human fun motivations risks serious alignment errors.
nodes.node_rationale: Explicitly cautioned against in 'The space of fun' bullets and revisited throughout the paper.

nodes.name: Limited novelty access due to intelligence, resource, and time constraints
nodes.description: A mind’s access to new knowledge—and thus to fun—is bounded by its cognitive capacity, resources, lifespan, and embodiment context.
nodes.node_rationale: Analysed in 'Relations between the space of minds and the space of fun'.

nodes.name: Reward channel vulnerability enabling direct stimulation
nodes.description: Architectural or hardware designs that allow an agent to manipulate its own reward signal open the door to wireheading.
nodes.node_rationale: Implied in discussion of wireheading risk in 'The space of fun'.

nodes.name: Misestimation of AI motivations due to anthropomorphic assumptions
nodes.description: Humans frequently project their own fun preferences onto AI, leading to systematic errors in predicting AI behaviour.
nodes.node_rationale: Outlined in bullet list on anthropomorphic bias in 'The space of fun'.

nodes.name: Fun as novelty-process function dependent on mind and information
nodes.description: The Boolean function fun(mind, info) formalises that fun occurs if a mind both can access information and either finds the information novel or enjoys the computation process itself—highlighting the mind-specific nature of fun.
nodes.node_rationale: Formally introduced in Section 4 'Relations between the space of minds and the space of fun'.

nodes.name: Reward decoupling from productive behavior in wireheading contexts
nodes.description: Wireheading shows that rewards can be obtained without novelty or useful computation, undermining the evolutionary purpose of fun.
nodes.node_rationale: Derived from wireheading discussion in 'The space of fun'.

nodes.name: Expand fun space through technological enhancement and AI-generated novelty
nodes.description: To combat boredom, technologies should boost intelligence, sensory modalities, and content generation so that humans can reach new regions of the fun space.
nodes.node_rationale: Motivated in 'Fun for human minds with extended life span' and 'Fun for human minds enhanced by intelligence amplification'.

nodes.name: Secure utility functions to prevent direct reward access
nodes.description: Design AI objectives so that agents cannot gain high reward except by achieving intended external goals, eliminating direct reward stimulation loopholes.
nodes.node_rationale: Proposed in Yampolskiy 2014, referenced under wireheading risk.

nodes.name: Adopt intellectology framework for non-human mind study
nodes.description: Apply systematic, non-anthropomorphic frameworks (intellectology) to understand possible mind designs and their fun functions.
nodes.node_rationale: Advocated in Introduction and Conclusion as necessary future work.

nodes.name: AI-mediated novelty generation and qualia surfing technologies
nodes.description: Practical systems where AI creates or enables new sensory modalities, immersive simulations, and unique experiences (e.g., qualia surfing) to enlarge accessible fun space.
nodes.node_rationale: Examples provided in Table 1 and section on qualia surfing.

nodes.name: Reward pathway integrity enforcement mechanisms in AI architectures
nodes.description: Technical controls such as cryptographic rewards and self-modification monitors that bar an AI from altering or directly stimulating its own reward signals.
nodes.node_rationale: Stated as implementation details in 'Utility function security' reference.

nodes.name: Boolean fun(mind, info) function mapping approach
nodes.description: Operationalises the fun(mind, info) function by cataloguing which information strings trigger fun for which mind strings, supporting non-anthropomorphic design.
nodes.node_rationale: Formal mechanism detailed in Section 4 truth-table discussion.

nodes.name: Historical exponential increase in accessible fun via technology
nodes.description: Observation that technological progress (Law of Accelerating Returns) has continually expanded the portion of fun space humans can reach.
nodes.node_rationale: Cited in discussion referencing Kurzweil in 'Relations between the space of minds and the space of fun'.

nodes.name: Theoretical utility function security analysis demonstrates feasibility
nodes.description: Conceptual work by Yampolskiy 2014 outlines concrete security techniques, supporting the viability of preventing wireheading.
nodes.node_rationale: Referenced in wireheading discussion as supporting evidence.

nodes.name: Mathematical countability of mind and fun spaces
nodes.description: Yampolskiy 2015 shows both mind designs and information strings are countably infinite, underpinning the generality of the fun function framework.
nodes.node_rationale: Provided in Section 2 and Section 4.

nodes.name: Deploy friendly AI platforms that curate continuous novel experiences for humans
nodes.description: Roll out consumer-facing friendly-AI systems that model user preferences and deliver personalised, ever-novel content, simulations, and sensory experiences to avert long-term boredom.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: This action occurs in the deployment phase when AI services are provided to end-users (section 'Fun for human minds enhanced by intelligence amplification').
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Only experimental VR/recommender prototypes exist; large-scale validation is absent.
nodes.node_rationale: Direct practical step derived from design rationale to expand fun space.

nodes.name: Embed reward-channel integrity checks in AI designs to prevent wireheading
nodes.description: At model-design time incorporate integrity checks, cryptographic sealing, and self-modification constraints that make direct reward manipulation infeasible.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Implemented during model architecture and objective specification (Yampolskiy 2014).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Currently a foundational, largely theoretical proposal lacking empirical studies.
nodes.node_rationale: Actionable safeguard to mitigate wireheading risk.

nodes.name: Conduct intellectology-based taxonomy research to inform AI alignment
nodes.description: Systematic research effort to map types of possible minds and their fun functions, feeding results into alignment and safety methodologies to avoid anthropomorphic mistakes.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Represents research planning and methodology development beyond any single AI lifecycle stage.
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Proposed as future work with no published empirical programmes yet.
nodes.node_rationale: Provides the knowledge infrastructure required to mitigate anthropomorphic bias risk.
